metadata.title: Sources of History
metadata.subject: History
metadata.description: Material, Written, and Oral sources of Medieval Indian History.

preAssessment.question: Which of the following is a material source of history?
The period from the 9th century AD to the end of the 18th century AD is considered as:

concepts.title: Material Sources: The Physical Evidence
concepts.content: Material sources include forts, memorials, buildings, cave sculptures, inscriptions, coins, and weapons. In Medieval India, forts like Raigad and coins like the Shivrai or the Hon are crucial for understanding the economic condition and administration of the time.
keyPoints: Forts have an important place among material sources
Coins tell us about the Emperor's reign and religion
Inscriptions are considered very reliable as they are permanent
concepts.funFact: Shivrai coins were made of copper, while the Hon was a gold coin used in the Maratha Empire!

concepts.title: Written Sources: The Recorded Word
concepts.content: Written sources include the script (Modi, Devanagari, Arabic, Persian), biographies of kings, travelogues by foreign travelers (like Ibn Battuta), and official documents. Bakhars are a unique type of written source from the Medieval period, containing chronicles of heroic deeds.
keyPoints: Bakhars help us understand the political happenings and social life
Modi and Persian were major scripts used in administration
Travelogues provide an outsider's view of Indian society
concepts.funFact: 'Tawarikh' means the sequence of events (dates) in Arabic!

concepts.title: Oral Sources: The Living History
concepts.content: Oral sources consist of folk songs, Powadas, stories, myths, and legends passed down from generation to generation. Powadas were particularly important during the Maratha period to inspire soldiers and describe the bravery of leaders like Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj.
keyPoints: Oral sources preserve history that isn't written down
Powadas are rhythmic and highly motivating
They reflect the emotions and values of the people
concepts.funFact: The Powada on the life of Tanaji Malusare is one of the most famous examples of oral history!
